Infinity Nikki is just a mix of Genshin Impact and Wuthering Waves but instead of gambling for cute characters, you gamble for outfits and makeup. 

The game is 100% made for the women audience, but if you a chill dude who likes fashion and rpgs then Id recommend it.

The only downside for most people would be the lack of combat. Dont get me wrong there are still enemies to fight, but they are all one-shot no matter your level. Since the game is designed to mainly focus on styling of clothing and styling battles, the enemy battles are simple and easy to pass.
I personally quite like the combat being simple, since it doesnt pull you away from the actual point of the game, and it makes it easy for people who dont have much combat experience in games.

There are also occasionally a few bugs while in dialog, as well as the game freezing while switching tabs. But nothing insane or game breaking has happened to me. 

Otherwise I 100% recommend this game.  I absolutely love it so far. The costumes are amazing and the stories are decently well done, with amazing art and animation. I can not stress about how insanely good the animation is. 
I hope anyone reading this will give it a go! >:3

I've been playing this game daily for several months now. Having wracked up over 350 hours, I'm torn as to whether I can recommend it. While I appreciate the sweet, chilled out vibe and beauty of the game, there are a few major issues.

Pros:
. The outfit design for this game is otherworldly! It's truly a beautiful game, with elements including dress-up, RPG and story-focus, exploration, puzzles, dailies and house building. All of which are designed to visually please.
. You can choose when to interact with the multiplayer aspects of the game. It runs as a single player with elements of multiplayer interaction.
. There are lots of mini games and puzzles, with new and continuous content release each month.
. Best home building I've seen in a game, and I've played a lot of home builders in my time!
. Really well coded game. Having played as much as I have, I've rarely encountered bugs. It's really solid.
. Calming and relaxing gameplay with chill vibes. Lots of room for customisation, with a focus on dress-up and outfit creation.
. It feels like the devs really take feedback on board.
. You get a lot out the F2P aspect, basically the whole game. Certain outfits come with abilities, but this does not effect the game or story whatsoever. 
. Exploration is really fun!
. I love taking beautiful pictures of Nikki dressed up all sweet. The scope for this is huge, with loads of poses and places to take pictures and share them with the community. Granted, this aspect will cost you really money in the long-run, as the diamonds you get at the start of the game will soon deplete, which is when you'll need to start forking out real dosh!

Cons:
. The biggest issue for me is the monthly outfit acquisition. You spend real money to buy diamonds for outfits - okay fine. But here's the kicker - outfit pieces aren't guaranteed even after spending real money. I've spent up to Â£40 on a single outfit before, and still not received the entire thing because of bad luck drawing each piece. It's basically a lottery. I think this is completely unacceptable. 
. The multiplayer aspect of the game is very limited. You can share snapshots: pictures you take around the world. You can view other player snapshots and like them. You can "reveal" players in one particular area (with their consent), but ultimately there isn't much interaction between players. I'd say that this was a singleplayer, with very limited multiplayer aspects.
. The stories are sometimes long and boring.
. It's impossible to complete collection, as outfits become unavailable after the season ends. For those who like to neatly collect and complete, this is a real nightmare. Besides, you'd literally need to spend thousands in order to collect everything. Very unsatisfying. 
. The dailies are an absolute drag.

Overall, I've enjoyed playing this game. I wouldn't mind paying for outfits if it wasn't a literal lottery each time. For this reason alone, I'm considering quitting, because the dress-up and picture taking aspects were the most appealing for me. Once you're up to date with the content, this aspect becomes pretty important.

This game is incredible. One of the best games I've played in my life truly. While I have few hours on steam, I've been playing the game since launch and have logged over 400 hours on the game overall at the time of this review. I play it every single day. A majority of the negative reviews on this game came from a barrage of upset players during a rough update where the game admittedly struggled with a lot of bugs, glitches, and was unplayable for some. The dress up aspect is hands down the best of anything I've ever played. There's so much content and so many outfits I could spend hours just playing dress up. For a franchise that was previously exclusively a mobile game, I am genuinely impressed with how they've created such an amazing open world experience on multiple platforms INCLUDING mobile. 

Cozy? Well... it has it's moments. It's a good mix of cozy (farming mats, exploration, dress up, photo taking, gardening, etc) and some pretty difficult combat and puzzles. I've been surprised at how much I've struggled in some of the boss fights. 

It's important to remember that this is a gacha game and with that, survives off of predatory money grabbing micro transactions and gambling. It is completely possible to play and enjoy this expansive game without spending a penny, but it does take some self control and some missing out on certain things. Be cautious playing if you have a history of gambling addictions or irresponsible spending. With that being said, it's a free to play game so in most cases it doesn't hurt to give it a shot.

As someone who played this game since the original release back in December, the most recent patch has outright ruined the game for me and many others. Ultimately it comes down to the following reasons:

1. The company that develops this game (Paper Games in China) has a long history of being greedypouchs, however, for the first 5-6 months of this game, they had struck an okay balance between generating decent revenue and having enough players okay with the prices that they are willing to spend regardless of it being kind of pricey. But, now we have seen their greed come through in this most recent patch. The rewards for adding this game to wishlist on steam were teased and then retroactively changed after we hit milestone, making players up. They showed us this lovely livestream teasing a lot of the new features and regions coming in 1.5, and made a point of saying "No broken promises."

2. This patch turned out to be more than just broken promises, it was also broken trust. It started by everyone, new and old alike, being dumped into a 15 minute unskippable cutscene + story sequence that effectively kidnapped you from where you logged out last. Then this sequence would go into a massive lore dump dialogue that would effectively ruin some of the communities favorite characters and any chance of seeing them by effectively saying "The world suddenly ended" (and we didn't even get to see it, just the aftermath) and "Giovanni Turned Evil" and "Ena sacrificed herself". It wasn't until later we would realize that this unskippable cutscene became the new player tutorial as well, which completely retconned the introduction of the game for new players.

3. This patch was buggy to all hell. I've played early access games (Like ARK when it first released) and many many others, but this takes the cake for one of the buggiest experience ever. Cutscene failures, Dyeing system not applying colors correctly, Story Quest markers broken and having untranslated text at times, Minigames not functional, Serenity Island straight up missing collision in big parts of the map (this was not just some small corner). This was alpha testing level bugs, but they released it this way for their players, effectively making us into unpaid beta testers for weeks. From the start, many PS5 players were unable to launch the game with this patch, and some of them (the ones who refused to reinstall and lose their pictures, or those who do not have a 2nd device to try unsticking whatever got stuck with their accounts) are unable to log in to this moment over 3 weeks later. When someone finally heard back from Customer Support about this issue, they were told that the downtime (That was infold's fault) was "not compensable" and to "Please log in on another device", which completely ignores folks who only have a PS5 and especially those who paided for monthly passes that WILL continue counting down regardless of if you login or not. These passes give limited currency for the Gacha system, and they were paid for with real world money.

The gacha system is also a point of issue. This patch, they released 11-piece outfits. Historically, it has been 10 or 9, but most often 10. It's up to 20 pity per piece, so that's 200 pity (which the exact cost may vary but up to a couple hundred dollars simply for completing the outfit once). Outfits have special abilities that can only be used with the full outfit, so it's often recommended to complete them. These new outfits were no exception, and by being 11 pieces, they were changed to 220 max pity if you wanted the complete set. This is effectively a pity increase and it came with 0 extra compensation from events for the increased pity, and additionally, the company tried silently changing the cooldown on the endgame mode that contributes to freebie currency to be 21 days instead of 14. This negatively impacted our freebies at the same exact time they were increasing the pity. Additionally, it's worth noting that 1 piece out of both fits (the socks) are completely invisible when wearing the full set due to the long skirts. This begs the question of "Was these socks needed for the fit, or perhaps for your wallet?".

The backlash: Many members of the community have been vocal from Global and CN alike in their dissatisfaction. About a day or 2 after the release, the company released a public apology that gave 20 draws for the limited banners and 10 for the standard, apologizing for the bugs, the dissatisfaction with the dye system, and most importantly the increased pity. They promised no 5* fits will exceed 11 pieces, which was still considered expensive by many. Additionally, previous nikki games have featured 6* fits, so this did not set many at ease, including myself. They did confirm adjusting the endgame mode to be every 1st/16th of the month, however this is still a downgrade from the 14days we had before. Overall, this apology was unsatisfactory, and became less and less satisfactory with each passing day with more and more bugs. Over the next 2 weeks, players have attempted boycotts (later renamed to Girlcott due to some censorship on various social platforms such as discord/reddit) for various reasons, many for the reasons listed above along with some others I'll list very quickly:
- One of the events ingame has an IRL 2 hours window tied to your game server that you must participant in order to receive rewards
- The Dye system was teased in a way that implied using materials from the open world, but ended up being a very limited currency that you could buy from the shop (it's expensive). The RGB slider that you get from maxing out a 5* fit requires unlocking all the previous colors to use, making it even more expensive! Additionally, colors like black and white are locked behind evolutions, some of which are obtained from pulling the fit more than once. 4* don't even have black and white in some cases.
- The Sea of Stars region is extremely disappointing from a gameplay perspective. We have 4 activities and 3 of them are very childish, like riding a See-saw, or Jumping on a bubble once, or turning into random animals in a ball pit. The dailies missions they introduced for this area are basically community service of collect these 20 shells and put them in the bucket. They introduced these new stars on this map for the new heart of infinity shard, which have 2 outfits you can unlock from it. These stars respawn 3 per day, but there was a bug that caused NA/EU to be able to collect twice. Rather than just give ASIA extra stars to fix it, they attempted to retroactively remove stars from those who duped, but many didn't even know it was a bug in the first place, and some got retracted without exploiting and some got to keep their stars. Additionally, a couple of people have reported having their limited gacha currencies being manipulated after the star adjustments went in, which is a very scary prospect for a Gacha Game.
- The shop featured an illegal bathtub pack, where it was offered for a limited time ONLY at 10$ from a "discounted" 50$. This item was never available for 50$ and never will because it will be removed from the store after 1.5

Saturday/Sunday (depending on timezone), we finally got another reply. I'll explain the highlights:

After playing this game consistently through every version patch since this games release, unfortunately the performance has only decreased. It has become nearly unplayable with the game taking 10-20 minutes to launch every time you open it, this is because they frequently patch bugs but you must restart the entire client every time it does this. The game launcher has recently introduced a new issue where it's process does not stop properly so you may be forced to restart your PC just to play the game. I won't even get into the large number of in game bugs, there are too many to talk about. 

There have been has been no new major region additions since launch but there have been new maps added (just singular islands). Events have been mostly the same recycled content since launch as well with little variety. The patch that I am writing this review in introduced the housing system - it is absolutely terrible. You must collect hundreds of materials which cannot be auto-farmed/completed quickly as far as I am aware to make even a single chair. There are additional wait times on creating the furniture, new currencies and battlepasses tied to it as well. 

As the main feature of the game is dress up, I will definitely give credit where it is due - the fabric textures and clothing look stunning and have been the reason I kept playing. There are definitely significant problems though and most of that is the lack of "normal" clothing items and the dyeing system. Certain clothing items can have their colour changed but the problem behind this is that most colours are locked behind owning duplicates, AKA. A paywall. Not to mention the separate currency with several tiers of rarity that have to be used to unlock a small array of colours - this has to be done for every single item of clothing. A lot of the clothing pieces are dresses, it's quite hard to create any non-feminine outfit. This problem can definitely be remedied, the best patch they did was the Danqing update which gave us a lot of Chinese inspired outfits and a few more gender neutral / masculine options but for the most part, clothing items are almost exclusively European / western style clothes with little variety. 

TLDR: The clothing and dress-up system is pretty good but you'll definitely feel that it's lacklustre and you cant create a whole lot of outfits because you'll be outright lacking in clothing or you just can't dye it the colour you want. Everything else in the game feels pretty terrible.
